Problem:
Consider the eigenvalue problem in the context of an operator \( L \) defined on a complex function space whereby \( Lf = \lambda f \). We analyze the effects of altering this relation by an integral transform \( T \) defined by \( (Tf)(x) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty k(x,t)f(t) dt \), where \( k(x, t) \) is a given kernel function.

If the transformation \( T \) is applied to a function \( f \) that is an eigenfunction of \( L \) with eigenvalue \( \lambda \), and \( T \) is known not to commute with \( L \), will \( T f \) necessarily be an eigenfunction of \( L \)?
Explanation: Since \( T \) does not commute with \( L \), applying \( T \) to an eigenfunction \( f \) of \( L \) could alter the function so that it is no longer an eigenfunction of \( L \). The non-commutativity implies that the order of operations between \( T \) and \( L \) affects the output, hence \( L(Tf) \neq \lambda (Tf) \).
